messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> I don't see how having more that one assert "fights against" JUnit (what
> does this even mean?) and in the code that I see every day, very few tests
> contain only one assert. Especially if your tests require two or three
> statements to set up in the test method (not in setUp()), in which case
> there is even more to be gained to run more than one assert so you don't
> have to duplicate this code in other test methods.

The sophomores taking MIT's software engineering lab were given a test
suite last week that had dozens of asserts per test method. One student
managed to have an infinite loop in one of her methods. To figure out
which of the twenty calls to that method in a single test was causing
the infinite loop, she had no choice but to put printlns between each
assert. Certainly if I saw this in my own code (rather than code my
class staff gave me), I would think strongly about separating each of
those asserts into its own method.

More test methods mean more information: with 20 asserts and 20 tests, I
know exactly which of the asserts fail. In one test method, I know only
the first.

> Also, the fix you show in your documentation is simplistic. What if the
> code to be extracted is specific to that test method? If you move it to
> setUp(), you are suddenly charging *all* the other test methods of
> that same
> class with this set up cost that they have no need for.

Or you could create a new class. Is that too expensive?

As the FAQ says, I like to take the temptation to put more than one
assert in a method as a sign that I could do something better with my
design. If there are two or three lines of setup, could that be a single
line in a better API? If testing one idea requires three different
accessor calls, could I create a single accessor or equals method that
would do that work? If I can't think of names for the different tests,
are they really testing different things?

One downside is that lots of methods does take up a lot of screen space
in my IDE. Unless Java introduces an "in-line block" syntax, however,
it's probably the best we can do for now.

David Saff
